images.summary: This site plan for the Brophy Residence shows the layout of the property, including the existing 2-storey house and a proposed 1-storey addition. The plan outlines property boundaries, setbacks, and the location of the driveway and sidewalk. Zoning information is provided, indicating a front yard setback of 4.5 meters, interior side yard setback of 1.2 meters, exterior side yard setback of 3.0 meters, and rear yard setback of 6.0 meters. The total permitted lot coverage is 35%, with the existing building area at 116.5 square meters and the proposed building area at 141.5 square meters, resulting in a proposed total lot coverage of 25.8%. The plan is drawn at a scale of 1:150.

images.text_verbatim:
TYPICAL STAIR
ALL STAIRS, HANDRAILS AND GUARDS ARE TO CONFORM TO SECTION 9.8 OF THE O.B.C.
LANDINGS, PORCHES, DECKS, WALKWAYS, ETC. GREATER THAN 24" ABOVE FINISHED GRADE OR FINISHED FLOOR, SHALL BE PROVIDED WITH A GUARD RAIL AS PER O.B.C.
MIN. CEILING HT. 6'-5"
MIN. 36" GUARD
MIN. 4" MAX. 7" RISE
MIN. 10" MAX. 14" RUN
images.summary: This detail illustrates a typical stair design, specifying that all stairs, handrails, and guards must conform to Section 9.8 of the Ontario Building Code (O.B.C.). It includes requirements for landings, porches, decks, and walkways that are more than 24 inches above finished grade or floor, which must have guard rails. The minimum ceiling height is 6'-5", with a minimum guard height of 36 inches. The rise of the stairs is between 4 and 7 inches, and the run is between 10 and 14 inches.

images.summary: These notes provide detailed information on foundation and loading specifications. Foundation notes specify that all concrete walls are 9 inches thick with a strength of 25 MPa, and footings are 20 MPa. Crawl spaces or basement floors must have a floor drain, and footings are based on soil with a bearing capacity of 75 kPa or greater. Anchor bolts are to be installed on top of the concrete foundation, spaced no further than 6'-10" on center. Weeping tiles with cloth sleeves and crushed stone cover are required around footings. Loading notes specify snow loads, dead loads, and live loads for different building components, including roof, ceiling, and floor. The location is London, ON, with specific kPa values for snow and dead loads. Dimensions notes clarify measurement practices for interior and exterior dimensions.

The area for the operable portion of the window must be at least 8". The hatched area indicates a minimum unobstructed opening of 3.8 square feet with no dimension less than 18 inches. The drawing is certified by a professional engineer with project number 25-01-099. The detail is not to scale (N.T.S).

images.summary: This foundation plan illustrates the existing and proposed foundation layout. It includes a 9' poured concrete foundation wall with an 18"x6" concrete footing, typical throughout. A new 2x4 sill plate, reduced to 1 1/4" thickness, is secured to the existing foundation wall using 3/8" anchor screws staggered at 24" on center, complete with a sill gasket. The plan specifies drilling and epoxying 18" long 15M dowels at 24" on center into the existing foundation, with a minimum 6" embedment. The drawing emphasizes not undermining existing footings or walls. The finished basement floor should match the height of the existing basement floor. The plan includes various rooms such as the existing recreation room, powder room, and laundry, with specific dimensions and notes on joists and bracing. Section callout A/3 is present.

images.summary: This main floor plan shows the layout of the living room, sitting room, and kitchen/dining area. The exterior wall consists of 3 1/2" brick, 1" air space, and various layers including 15# asphalt building paper or Tyvek air barrier, 7/16" OSB sheathing, 2x6 studs at 16" on center, R-20 batt insulation, 6 mil poly vapor barrier, and 1/2" drywall. Engineered roof trusses are spaced at 24" on center, with bracing as per manufacturer specifications. Existing doors and windows are to be removed and replaced with new, smaller doorways, retaining existing lintels. The plan includes section callout A/3 and element callouts L1 and L2.

images.summary: This lintel schedule provides specifications for various lintels used in the construction. Lintel L1 supports a maximum opening of 4'-5" and consists of two 2x6 members with one stud bearing and one king stud. Lintel L2 supports a maximum opening of 5'-4" and consists of two 2x8 members with one stud bearing and one king stud. Lintel L3 supports a maximum opening of 9'-0" and consists of two 1 3/4x9 1/2" 2.0E 3100Fb LVL members with two studs bearing and one king stud. The schedule advises consulting the truss manufacturer or drawing designer if unexpected point loads are located on any headers within the building.

images.summary: This image contains general notes related to construction compliance and specifications. The existing main floor area is 113 square feet, while the proposed main floor area is 1103 square feet. The existing second floor area is 862 square feet, and the garage area is 462 square feet. Construction must comply with the latest O.B.C and local by-laws. Lintels above exterior doors and windows are specified as 2-ply with 2-1/2" rigid insulation fillers unless noted otherwise. Window and door sizes must be verified with the contractor or owner before construction. Installation instructions for nailing/bolt patterns of different ply LVL's should be followed. All vapour barriers must be caulked and sealed at all penetrations. Interior load-bearing studs are to be 16" on center with one row of solid blocking at mid-height. Smoke alarm systems and carbon dioxide detectors with visual components are required in every bedroom and adjacent hallways, as well as on each floor, including the basement, as per OBC 9.10.18, except as permitted by OBC 9.10.19.8.

images.summary: This image provides general notes focusing on construction verification and safety requirements. Window and door sizes must be checked and verified with the contractor or owner before construction. Installation instructions for nailing/bolt patterns of different ply LVL's should be followed. Vapour barriers must be caulked and sealed at all penetrations. Interior load-bearing studs are specified to be 16 inches on center with one row of solid blocking at mid-height. Smoke alarm systems and carbon dioxide detectors with visual components are required in every bedroom and adjacent hallways, as well as on each floor, including the basement, as per OBC 9.10.18, except as permitted by OBC 9.10.19.8.

images.summary: This image contains general notes regarding floor areas and construction compliance. The existing main floor area is 113 square feet, and the proposed main floor area is 1103 square feet. The existing second floor area is 862 square feet, and the garage area is 462 square feet. Construction must comply with the latest O.B.C and local by-laws. Lintels above exterior doors and windows are specified as 2-ply with 2-1/2" rigid insulation fillers unless noted otherwise. Window and door rough stud openings should be referred to in the manufacturer’s manual. Exterior doors and windows must comply with forced entry requirements as per OBC 9.6.6 and 9.6.1.

images.summary: This image shows the west elevation of a building, featuring brick/stone and vinyl siding. Key components include windows, footing, subfloor, and plate. The elevation notes specify a minimum of 6 feet between the window and roof peak, with adjustments made on-site as needed. The line of the cathedral ceiling (LINE OF CATH. CLG.) is indicated. Weeping holes are spaced at 3'1" on center. Stairs and hand/guard rails must comply with OBC 9.8 & SB-1. The basement egress windows must have an unobstructed opening of at least 3.75 square feet, with no dimension less than 15 inches and a clearance of not less than 22 inches in front of the window well. The drawing scale is 1/8" = 1'-0".

images.summary: This cross section illustrates the proposed living room addition, showing the relationship between existing and new structures. The section includes existing exterior walls, roof, and floor structures, as well as the proposed living room and sitting room. A new 2x4 stud framed wall is introduced for pocket doors, with a 1-inch gap between the existing and new structures. The section details a new 2x4 sill plate, ripped to 1/4-inch thickness, secured to the existing foundation wall with 3/8-inch anchor screws staggered at 24 inches on center. The thermal performance for additions is specified, with R-values for various components. The section also notes the unfinished basement and existing concrete foundation wall and slab.

images.summary: This wall section detail illustrates the construction of a wall assembly, including asphalt shingles, vinyl siding, and a 3 1/2-inch stone veneer with a 1-foot air space. The section specifies a minimum 2x4 sill plate with a sill gasket and 1/2-inch anchor bolts spaced at 48 inches on center. The drainage layer and damp proofing are detailed, along with a 9-inch concrete foundation wall and 2-inch rigid insulation (R-12). The wall includes 2x4 studs at 24 inches on center with R-14 batt insulation and a 6 mil poly air/vapor barrier. The roof assembly features attic venting, ice/rain shield, roof sheathing with H-clips, and pre-engineered roof trusses at 24 inches on center. The section also details the concrete footing and slab on undisturbed soil or compacted granular fill.

images.summary: This image contains notes regarding the north elevation's glazing and thermal performance. The maximum area of glazing in the exterior wall is governed by OBC Table 9.10.15.4, with a total wall area of 130 sq.ft. (6.7m²) and total window area of 36 sq.ft. (3.34m²). The distance from the house face to the property line is 4.27 meters, with a window to wall ratio of 5%, and a maximum allowable ratio of 28%. Thermal performance specifications for additions in Zone 1 are provided, including R-values for ceilings, exposed floors, walls above grade, and basement walls, as well as an energy rating for windows and sliding glass doors.

images.summary: This detail illustrates the application of an air/vapor (A/V) barrier at wall openings and penetrations. The wall assembly includes studs as per plan, a 6 Mil Poly A/V Barrier, and sheathing. The barrier is sealed with caulking at wall penetrations and to surrounding flanges. The assembly features 1-inch rigid insulation, brick/stone veneer, and wall cladding with a 1-inch air space. The interior finish includes 1/2-inch drywall. The detail emphasizes the continuous surround of the A/V barrier to ensure airtightness.

images.summary: This detail shows the A/V barrier application at a sill plate. The wall assembly includes a 6 Mil Poly A/V Barrier overlapped, taped, and sealed to R-12 blanket insulation. The detail specifies R-22 batt insulation within the wall cavity. The sill plate is secured with 1/2-inch anchor bolts spaced 48 inches on center. The assembly includes a sill gasket and 2-inch rigid insulation. The exterior finish and slope grade are also indicated. The detail ensures the vapor barrier is sealed to the air barrier wrap, maintaining airtightness.

images.summary: This detail illustrates the A/V barrier application at ceiling penetrations, specifically around light fixtures. The assembly includes a 6 Mil Poly A/V Barrier providing a continuous surround, sealed to the surrounding flange with caulking. The ceiling is finished with 1/2-inch drywall, and attic insulation is indicated above the barrier. This detail ensures that the A/V barrier maintains its integrity around penetrations to prevent air leakage.

images.summary: This detail shows the A/V barrier application at wall cladding and window trim. The assembly includes a 6 Mil Poly A/V Barrier, 1-inch rigid insulation, and 1/2-inch drywall. Adhesive tape is used to fasten the barrier to the UNDW and rigid insulation. The detail specifies caulking and backer bead for sealing, with foam insulation and UNDW trim. The seams are caulked to ensure airtightness. This detail highlights the integration of the A/V barrier with wall cladding and window trim to prevent air leakage.

images.summary: This detail illustrates the A/V barrier application at sills. The assembly includes a 6 Mil Poly A/V Barrier, 1-inch rigid insulation, and 1/2-inch drywall. The barrier is fastened with adhesive tape to the UNDW and rigid insulation. The detail features masonry veneer and a steel brick lintel. Caulking and backer bead are used for sealing, with foam insulation and UNDW trim. All seams are caulked to ensure airtightness. This detail ensures the integration of the A/V barrier with sills to prevent air leakage.
